elements.content: Two novel heterobimetallic three-dimensional coordination polymers, [Cu2Na4L2(CH3OH)2.3(H2O)5.2]·1.7H2O (1) and [CuNa2L(H2O)3.88]·H2O (2), have been obtained by assembling a bis-oxamate copper(II) complex with sodium ions (L = 4,4′-sulfonylbis(phenylene)bis(oxamate). Both coordination frameworks are constructed by connecting {Cu4L4} crosslike anionic units by sodium ions forming polymers with different topologies. The magnetic susceptibility data shows weak antiferromagnetic interaction for both compounds.
elements.clean_text: Two novel heterobimetallic three-dimensional coordination polymers, [Cu2Na4L2(CH3OH)2.3(H2O)5.2]⋅1.7H2O (1) and [CuNa2L(H2O)3.88]⋅H2O (2), have been obtained by assembling a bis-oxamate copper(II) complex with sodium ions (L = 4,4'-sulfonylbis(phenylene)bis(oxamate). Both coordination frameworks are constructed by connecting {Cu4L4} crosslike anionic units by sodium ions forming polymers with different topologies. The magnetic susceptibility data shows weak antiferromagnetic interaction for both compounds.

elements.content: Two novel heterobimetallic three-dimensional coordination polymers, [Cu2Na4L2(CH3OH)2.3(H2O)5.2]·1.7H2O (1) and [CuNa2L(H2O)3.88]·H2O (2) (L = 4,4′-sulfonylbis(phenylene)bis(oxamate), have been obtained. Both coordination frameworks are constructed by connecting {Cu4L4} crosslike anionic units by sodium ions forming polymers with different topologies. The magnetic susceptibility data shows weak antiferromagnetic interaction for both compounds.
elements.clean_text: Two novel heterobimetallic three-dimensional coordination polymers, [Cu2Na4L2(CH3OH)2.3(H2O)5.2]⋅1.7H2O (1) and [CuNa2L(H2O)3.88]⋅H2O (2) (L = 4,4'-sulfonylbis(phenylene)bis(oxamate), have been obtained. Both coordination frameworks are constructed by connecting {Cu4L4} crosslike anionic units by sodium ions forming polymers with different topologies. The magnetic susceptibility data shows weak antiferromagnetic interaction for both compounds.

elements.content: Bis-oxamate ligands played an important role in the history of molecular magnetism. Compounds illustrating basic concepts, such as irregular spin state structure and ferrimagnetic chains, as well as one of the very first molecule-based magnets were obtained by assembling bis-oxamate copper(II) building blocks with complex cations. In the first stage, manganese(II) was the favorite assembling cation because of its big spin. In fact, the synthetic strategy to obtain molecular magnets, developed by Kahn and his co-workers, was genuine crystal engineering avant la lettre. The use of bis-oxamate copper(II) complexes as metalloligands represents a powerful strategy for obtaining a rich variety of heterometallic complexes, ranging from discrete species to high-dimensional coordination polymers. This chemistry was recently enriched by Journaux, Lloret et al., who synthesized numerous bis-oxamate derivatives and their copper(II) complexes, playing with the relative positions of the coordinating groups. Novel coordination polymers exhibiting several network topologies, and combining the magnetic properties with other useful properties (porosity, chirality), have been obtained by assembling the bis-oxamate-copper(II) tectons with either paramagnetic or diamagnetic metal ions. Recently, bimetallic chains showing slow magnetic relaxation below the blocking temperature, typical of single-chain magnets, were obtained using copper(II) oxamate building blocks. In contrast to self-assembly methods, the synthetic approach known as “complex-as-ligand/complex-as-metal” have been described as an efficient technique to synthesize high nuclearity heterometallic compounds as well as coordination polymers, using copper(II)-alkali bimetallic bis-oxamate building blocks where bis-oxamate ligands were essential to obtain different spin topologies. Here, we present two novel heterobimetallic polymers, [Cu2Na4L2(CH3OH)2.3(H2O)5.2]·1.7H2O (1) and [CuNa2L(H2O)3.88]·H2O (2), which were obtained using an angular bis-oxamate tecton: 4,4′-sulfonylbis(phenylene)bis(oxamate). Due to their flexible angular V-shape, this ligand is a good candidate for building unusual networks and promoting a variety of structural motifs. In addition, its length makes this ligand very appealing in crystal engineering and can contribute to obtain polymers with quite different network topologies than reported for Cu(II)-alkali bimetallic bis-oxamate coordination compounds.

Compounds illustrating basic concepts, such as irregular spin state structure and ferrimagnetic chains, as well as one of the very first molecule-based magnets were obtained by assembling bis-oxamate copper(II) building blocks with complex cations. In the first stage, manganese(II) was the favorite assembling cation because of its big spin. In fact, the synthetic strategy to obtain molecular magnets, developed by Kahn and his co-workers, was genuine crystal engineering avant la lettre. The use of bis-oxamate copper(II) complexes as metalloligands represents a powerful strategy for obtaining a rich variety of heterometallic complexes, ranging from discrete species to high-dimensional coordination polymers. This chemistry was recently enriched by Journaux, Lloret et al., who synthesized numerous bis-oxamate derivatives and their copper(II) complexes, playing with the relative positions of the coordinating groups. Novel coordination polymers exhibiting several network topologies, and combining the magnetic properties with other useful properties (porosity, chirality), have been obtained by assembling the bis-oxamate-copper(II) tectons with either paramagnetic or diamagnetic metal ions. Recently, bimetallic chains showing slow magnetic relaxation below the blocking temperature, typical of single-chain magnets, were obtained using copper(II) oxamate building blocks. In contrast to self-assembly methods, the synthetic approach known as "complex-as-ligand/complex-as-metal" have been described as an efficient technique to synthesize high nuclearity heterometallic compounds as well as coordination polymers, using copper(II)-alkali bimetallic bis-oxamate building blocks where bis-oxamate ligands were essential to obtain different spin topologies. elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized by hydrolysis of the 4,4′-sulfonylbis(phenylamine)bis(ethyl-2-oxoacetate) (H2Et2L, chart 1 of the ) in an aqueous solution of sodium hydroxide followed by the addition of an aqueous solution of copper(II) nitrate. Methanol was carefully added to this solution, forming a layer. The green (1) and purple (2) crystals have been obtained simultaneously by a slow diffusion of the layers (see the for details). The crystal structures of both compounds have been solved and reveal the formation of quite interesting coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized by hydrolysis of the 4,4'-sulfonylbis(phenylamine)bis(ethyl-2-oxoacetate) (H2Et2L, chart 1 of the ) in an aqueous solution of sodium hydroxide followed by the addition of an aqueous solution of copper(II) nitrate. Methanol was carefully added to this solution, forming a layer. The green (1) and purple (2) crystals have been obtained simultaneously by a slow diffusion of the layers (see the  for details). The crystal structures of both compounds have been solved and reveal the formation of quite interesting coordination polymers.

elements.content: View of the tetranuclear copper metalloligand in complex 1 and its connectivities to the sodium ions. Symmetry codes: i = −1 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z; ii = −x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; iii = −x, 1 – y, 1 – z; iv = −1 – x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z.
elements.clean_text: 1  View of the tetranuclear copper metalloligand in complex 1 and its connectivities to the sodium ions. Symmetry codes: i = -1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z; ii = -x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; iii = -x, 1 - y, 1 - z; iv = -1 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two copper(II) and four sodium ions crystallographically nonequivalent (Figure S1 of the ). The solid-state architecture of 1 can easily be described observing that the four copper(II) ions and the two bis-oxamate ligands, L4–, generate a tetranuclear anionic complex, which further acts as a metalloligand toward the sodium cations (Figure ). Let us focus first on the tetranuclear copper complex, which shows a crosslike shape, as a result of the angular nature of the bis-oxamate ligands [the angles between the two carbon–sulfur bonds for each ligand are 102.9(3)° and 103.4(3)°]. The four sulfonyl groups point to the center of the cross. The arms of the cross are formed by two parallel p-phenylene rings belonging to two different ligand molecules. The short distance between these two rings with intermolecular carbon–carbon distances ranges between 3.47 and 3.90 Å (centroid–centroid distance: 3.68 Å) for the arm ending with Cu1 and 3.35 and 3.66 Å (centroid–centroid distance: 3.50 Å) for the arm ending with Cu2, indicating significant π–π stacking interactions. The copper(II) ions are pentacoordinated with a square-pyramidal geometry. For all the copper ions, the basal plane is formed by two oxygen and two nitrogen atoms arising from the two oxamate groups, with bond distances varying between 1.953(5)–1.969(5) Å for Cu1 and 1.957(5)–1.989(6) Å for Cu2. The apical position of Cu1 is occupied by an oxygen atom arising from the oxamate group coordinated to Cu2 that belongs to another cross, Cu1–O2B = 2.571(5) Å. The apical position of Cu2 is occupied by a water molecule (Cu2–O4w = 2.261(6) Å, Figure S2 of the ). The intracross diagonal distances between the copper ions are Cu1···Cu1 = 17.98 Å (−1 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z); Cu2···Cu2 = 18.39 Å (−1 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z). The intracross distances between the copper ions belonging to perpendicular arms are Cu1···Cu2 = 12.82 Å and Cu1···Cu2 = 12.89 Å (−1 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z).

The solid-state architecture of 1 can easily be described observing that the four copper(II) ions and the two bis-oxamate ligands, L4-, generate a tetranuclear anionic complex, which further acts as a metalloligand toward the sodium cations (Figure ). Let us focus first on the tetranuclear copper complex, which shows a crosslike shape, as a result of the angular nature of the bis-oxamate ligands [the angles between the two carbon-sulfur bonds for each ligand are 102.9(3)° and 103.4(3)°]. The four sulfonyl groups point to the center of the cross. The arms of the cross are formed by two parallel p-phenylene rings belonging to two different ligand molecules. The short distance between these two rings with intermolecular carbon-carbon distances ranges between 3.47 and 3.90 Å (centroid-centroid distance: 3.68 Å) for the arm ending with Cu1 and 3.35 and 3.66 Å (centroid-centroid distance: 3.50 Å) for the arm ending with Cu2, indicating significant π-π stacking interactions. The apical position of Cu2 is occupied by a water molecule (Cu2-O4w = 2.261(6) Å, Figure S2 of the ). The intracross diagonal distances between the copper ions are Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu1 = 17.98 Å (-1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z); Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu2 = 18.39 Å (-1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z). The intracross distances between the copper ions belonging to perpendicular arms are Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 = 12.82 Å and Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 = 12.89 Å (-1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z).

elements.content: Formation of the layers in crystal 1 by connecting the tetranuclear complexes with Na1 ions. Symmetry codes: i = −x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; ii = 1 – x, 1 – y, −z; iii = 2 – x, 0.5 + y, −0.5 – z; iv = 2 + x, y, −1 + z; v = −x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; vi = 1 – x, −y, −z; vii = 1 + x, 0.5 – y, −0.5 + z.
elements.clean_text: 2  Formation of the layers in crystal 1 by connecting the tetranuclear complexes with Na1 ions. Symmetry codes: i = -x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; ii = 1 - x, 1 - y, -z; iii = 2 - x, 0.5 + y, -0.5 - z; iv = 2 + x, y, -1 + z; v = -x, -0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; vi = 1 - x, -y, -z; vii = 1 + x, 0.5 - y, -0.5 + z.

elements.content: The tetranuclear anionic species are connected by the Na1 ions, forming layers as shown in Figure . Each Na1 ion is hexacoordinated by four peripheral oxamate oxygen atoms from two different crosses and by one methanol and one aqua ligand disposed in the trans positions. The shortest distance between the Na1 ions is 11.15 Å.

Each Na1 ion is hexacoordinated by four peripheral oxamate oxygen atoms from two different crosses and by one methanol and one aqua ligand disposed in the trans positions. The shortest distance between the Na1 ions is 11.15 Å.

elements.content: The connectivity of the tetranuclear copper(II) crosses in 1. The sulfonyl oxygen atoms have been removed for clarity; the phenylene groups have been represented as thick lines, the crosses being drawn with different colors. (a) Top view, the sodium ions are not represented. (b) Lateral view. Symmetry codes: i = −1 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z; ii = x, 0.5 – y, 0.5 + z; iii = −1 + x, y, z; iv = −1 – x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; v = −1 + x, 1 + y, z.
elements.clean_text: 3  The connectivity of the tetranuclear copper(II) crosses in 1. The sulfonyl oxygen atoms have been removed for clarity; the phenylene groups have been represented as thick lines, the crosses being drawn with different colors. (a) Top view, the sodium ions are not represented. (b) Lateral view. Symmetry codes: i = -1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z; ii = x, 0.5 - y, 0.5 + z; iii = -1 + x, y, z; iv = -1 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; v = -1 + x, 1 + y, z.

elements.content: The extension of the structure into the third dimension is more complicated. First of all, we recall that the crosses are connected by an equatorial–apical connection of copper ions belonging to different tetranuclear entities. Each cross is connected to four other crosses through these copper–copper interactions (Figure a). The space between the tetranuclear units is filled by the sodium ions (Figure b). The coordination spheres and the connectivity modes of the sodium ions are represented in Figures S3 and S4 of the . All the sodium ions are hexacoordinated. Two Na4 ions are coordinated by the sulfonyl oxygen atoms, above and below each cross (Figure S4 of the ). The coordination sphere of the Na4 ions is made by four sulfonyl and one oxamate (O7A) oxygen atoms and by one bridging water molecule (O1W). Each Na4 ion is bridged to the Na3 atom by an aqua ligand (O1W) and by a sulfonyl oxygen (O4A). The Na3 is further connected to Na2 by a bridging water molecule (O2W), and Na2 is connected to another sodium ion, Na2i, by a water molecule (O7W) (i = −x, −y, 1 – z). This water molecule is disordered over two positions. The relation between the layer depicted in Figure and Figure b is illustrated in Figure S5 of the , where only the blue and the dark green crosses are represented. The distances between the sodium ions are as follows: Na2···Na3 = 4.063; Na3···Na4 = 3.547; Na2···Na2 = 4.407 (−x, −y, 1 – z); and Na4···Na4 = 4.386 Å (−1 – x, −y, −z). Selected bond distances are collected in Table S2 of the .

First of all, we recall that the crosses are connected by an equatorial-apical connection of copper ions belonging to different tetranuclear entities. Each cross is connected to four other crosses through these copper-copper interactions (Figure a). The space between the tetranuclear units is filled by the sodium ions (Figure b). The coordination spheres and the connectivity modes of the sodium ions are represented in Figures S3 and S4 of the . All the sodium ions are hexacoordinated. Two Na4 ions are coordinated by the sulfonyl oxygen atoms, above and below each cross (Figure S4 of the ). The coordination sphere of the Na4 ions is made by four sulfonyl and one oxamate (O7A) oxygen atoms and by one bridging water molecule (O1W). Each Na4 ion is bridged to the Na3 atom by an aqua ligand (O1W) and by a sulfonyl oxygen (O4A). The Na3 is further connected to Na2 by a bridging water molecule (O2W), and Na2 is connected to another sodium ion, Na2i, by a water molecule (O7W) (i = -x, -y, 1 - z). This water molecule is disordered over two positions. The relation between the layer depicted in Figure  and Figure b is illustrated in Figure S5 of the , where only the blue and the dark green crosses are represented. The distances between the sodium ions are as follows: Na2⋅⋅⋅Na3 = 4.063; Na3⋅⋅⋅Na4 = 3.547; Na2⋅⋅⋅Na2 = 4.407 (-x, -y, 1 - z); and Na4⋅⋅⋅Na4 = 4.386 Å (-1 - x, -y, -z). Selected bond distances are collected in Table S2 of the .

elements.content: Layers made by the connectivity between the tetranuclear units and sodium ions in 2. Symmetry codes: i = 2 – x, 0.5 – y, 2.5 – z; ii = 1 – x, 0.5 – y, 2.5 – z; iii = 1.75 – x, y, 2.75 – z; iv = 1 – x, 0.25 + y, 1.25 + z; v = 1 – x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 – z; vi = −0.25 + x, 0.25 + y, 2.5 – z; vii = 2 – x, −0.5 – y, 2.5 – z; viii = −0.25 + x, −y, −0.25 + z; ix = 2.25 – x, −0.25 – y, −0.5 + z; x = 2 – x, 0.75 + y, −0.25 + z; xi = 2.25 – x, y, 2.25 – z; xii = −0.5 + x, −0.25 – y, 2.25 – z; xiii = −0.5 + x, y, −0.5 + z.

Symmetry codes: i = 2 - x, 0.5 - y, 2.5 - z; ii = 1 - x, 0.5 - y, 2.5 - z; iii = 1.75 - x, y, 2.75 - z; iv = 1 - x, 0.25 + y, 1.25 + z; v = 1 - x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 - z; vi = -0.25 + x, 0.25 + y, 2.5 - z; vii = 2 - x, -0.5 - y, 2.5 - z; viii = -0.25 + x, -y, -0.25 + z; ix = 2.25 - x, -0.25 - y, -0.5 + z; x = 2 - x, 0.75 + y, -0.25 + z; xi = 2.25 - x, y, 2.25 - z; xii = -0.5 + x, -0.25 - y, 2.25 - z; xiii = -0.5 + x, y, -0.5 + z.

elements.content: We will now discuss the crystal structure of 2. The asymmetric unit is shown in Figure S6 of the . Like in the case of compound 1, the anionic tetranuclear copper(II) crosslike entity is again assembled and acts as a metalloligand toward sodium ions (Figure S7 of the ). All the copper ions show a square planar stereochemistry, being coordinated by two oxamate groups, with bond lengths ranging between 1.931(5) and 1.959(5) Å. The intracross distances between the copper ions are almost the same: Cu1···Cu1 = 18.32 Å (2.25 – x, 1.25 – y, z) and Cu2···Cu2 = 18.31 Å (x, −0.75 – y, 2.25 – z). Both 1 and 2 are 3D coordination polymers but their topologies are different. In 2, the tetranuclear anionic Cu4L4 crosses are connected by the Na5, Na2, and Na4 ions, forming layers as shown in Figure , with these last two ions disordered over two positions with partial occupancy. The Cu2 and Na2 ions are bridge-coordinated by the oxamate group, forming the zigzag chain parallel to the b axis (Figure ), in contrast with the almost linear Cu1···Na1 chain observed for 1. The Na2 ion is coordinated by two oxygen atoms being bis-chelated by the oxamate group and by four bridging water molecules (O1W and O2W) (Figure ). The coordination sphere of the Na5 ion is made by four oxygen atoms that belong to two adjacent crosses and by four bridging water molecules (O2W). The Na4 is further connected to Na5 by water molecules (O2W) and by oxygen atoms from the oxamate group (O2) (Figure ). The opposite arms of each cross connected by a bridging Na5 ion are twisted by a torsion angle of 47.6°, and consequently, the chains formed by Cu1 and Na1 ions linking different layers (Figure a and Figure S8 of the ) and the description of the structure into the third dimension is quite complicated. First, two Na3 ions are coordinated by four sulfonyl oxygen atoms and by two bridging water molecules (O1W). Each Na3 ion is connected to the Na2 ion belonging to two different tetranuclear crosses (Figure a). In addition, a bridging water molecule (O2W) connects the Na2 ion to the Na5 ion belonging to adjacent layers (Figure S9 of the ), resulting in a complicated 3D framework, and the analysis of the packing diagram emphasized the self-interpenetration of two nets (Figure b and Figure S10 of the ).

elements.content: Crystal packing of 2 evidencing the connectivity between tetranuclear copper(II) crosses. The phenylene groups have been represented as thick lines. (a) View along the b axis: the black diagonal line represents the Cu1···Na1 chain. (b) Detail of the packing diagram highlighting the interpenetrated brown and blue nets. For clarity, the central cross was replaced by an orange line and the sulfonyl oxygen atoms and the Na2 and Na3 ions have been removed. Solid thick lines represent the Cu1···Na1 chain; dashed lines represent the connection between crosses by a bridging Na5 ion, and the gray line represents the Cu2···Na2 chain. Symmetry codes: i = 2.25 – x, 0.75 – y, −0.5 + z; ii = 0.5 + x, 1 + y, −0.5 + z; iii = 0.5 + x, 0.75 – y, 2.25 – z; iv = 2.25 – x, 1 + y, 2.25 – z.
elements.clean_text: 5  Crystal packing of 2 evidencing the connectivity between tetranuclear copper(II) crosses. The phenylene groups have been represented as thick lines. (a) View along the b axis: the black diagonal line represents the Cu1⋅⋅⋅Na1 chain. (b) Detail of the packing diagram highlighting the interpenetrated brown and blue nets. For clarity, the central cross was replaced by an orange line and the sulfonyl oxygen atoms and the Na2 and Na3 ions have been removed. Solid thick lines represent the Cu1⋅⋅⋅Na1 chain; dashed lines represent the connection between crosses by a bridging Na5 ion, and the gray line represents the Cu2⋅⋅⋅Na2 chain. Symmetry codes: i = 2.25 - x, 0.75 - y, -0.5 + z; ii = 0.5 + x, 1 + y, -0.5 + z; iii = 0.5 + x, 0.75 - y, 2.25 - z; iv = 2.25 - x, 1 + y, 2.25 - z.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of compound 1 have been investigated in the temperature range 2–285 K. The χMT versus T curve is presented in Figure S11 of the . The high temperature value of the χMT product is 1.52 cm3 mol–1 K and corresponds to four uncoupled copper(II) ions (2 mols of 1). Upon cooling, χMT remains constant down to 50 K and then it decreases abruptly, showing the onset of antiferromagnetic interactions. Since the intramolecular (intracross) distances between the copper ions are very large (12.82–17.98 Å), we discarded these exchange pathways. The strongest copper–copper exchange interaction is supposed to occur between Cu1 and Cu2, belonging to neighboring tetranuclear units and connected through their basal and apical positions. The distance between these copper ions is 5.507 Å. Since the magnetic orbital for the square pyramidal geometry, dx2–y2, is located in the basal plane, the exchange interaction between Cu1 and Cu2 is expected to be quite weak. Indeed, the best fit to the data, using the classical Bleaney–Bowers equation multiplied by 2, leads to J = −1.50 cm–1, g = 2.02 (H = −JS 1 S 2 ). The χMT versus T curve for 2 is presented in Figure S12 of the . The χMT product is 0.38 cm3 mol–1 K at 291 K, as expected for a noninteracting copper(II) ion with g = 2.0. Upon cooling, χMT remains constant down to 45 K and then it decreases, showing the onset of antiferromagnetic interactions. The strongest copper–copper exchange interaction is expected to occur through the shortest distance between Cu1 and Cu2 (5.18 Å), belonging to the neighboring tetranuclear units forming a chain parallel to the crystallographic direction a, then the magnetic susceptibility data was fitted using the isotropic uniform Heisenberg chain model. We fitted the magnetic data using an empirical expression, which reproduces the Bonner and Fisher’s numerical calculations. The magnetic susceptibility data was described for this model with least-squares best fit parameters: g = 2.01 and |J| = 0.80 cm–1.

The distance between these copper ions is 5.507 Å. Since the magnetic orbital for the square pyramidal geometry, dx2-y2, is located in the basal plane, the exchange interaction between Cu1 and Cu2 is expected to be quite weak. Indeed, the best fit to the data, using the classical Bleaney-Bowers equation multiplied by 2, leads to J = -1.50 cm-1, g = 2.02 (H = -JS  1  S  2 ). The χMT versus T curve for 2 is presented in Figure S12 of the . The χMT product is 0.38 cm3 mol-1 K at 291 K, as expected for a noninteracting copper(II) ion with g = 2.0. Upon cooling, χMT remains constant down to 45 K and then it decreases, showing the onset of antiferromagnetic interactions. The strongest copper-copper exchange interaction is expected to occur through the shortest distance between Cu1 and Cu2 (5.18 Å), belonging to the neighboring tetranuclear units forming a chain parallel to the crystallographic direction a, then the magnetic susceptibility data was fitted using the isotropic uniform Heisenberg chain model. We fitted the magnetic data using an empirical expression, which reproduces the Bonner and Fisher's numerical calculations. The magnetic susceptibility data was described for this model with least-squares best fit parameters: g = 2.01 and |J| = 0.80 cm-1.

elements.content: The new compounds we described in this paper show that the long angular 4,4′-sulfonylbis(phenylene)bis(oxamate) molecule has quite an interesting potential for crystal engineering. Although the 4,4′-sulfonylbis(phenylamine)bis(ethyl-2-oxoacetate) was reported in 1969, compounds 1 and 2 represent the very first coordination compounds obtained starting from this proligand. The anionic copper complex can act as a metalloligand toward various 3d and 4f ions, either naked or carrying blocking ligands. Further work is in progress in our laboratory and will be presented in subsequent papers.
elements.clean_text: The new compounds we described in this paper show that the long angular 4,4'-sulfonylbis(phenylene)bis(oxamate) molecule has quite an interesting potential for crystal engineering. Although the 4,4'-sulfonylbis(phenylamine)bis(ethyl-2-oxoacetate) was reported in 1969, compounds 1 and 2 represent the very first coordination compounds obtained starting from this proligand. The anionic copper complex can act as a metalloligand toward various 3d and 4f ions, either naked or carrying blocking ligands. Further work is in progress in our laboratory and will be presented in subsequent papers.

elements.content: Synthesis, crystallographic, and magnetic data for 1 and 2; chart of Et2H2L; table with crystal data and structure refinement for 1 and 2; table with the collection of interatomic distances in 1 and 2; Figures S1–S10 show details of the crystal structure of 1 and 2; Figures S11–S12 show the susceptibility magnetic data for 1 and 2; X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: The magnetic properties of compound 1 have been investigated in the temperature range 2–285 K. The χMT versus T curve is presented in Figure S11 of the . The high temperature value of the χMT product is 1.52 cm3 mol–1 K and corresponds to four uncoupled copper(II) ions (2 mols of 1). Upon cooling, χMT remains constant down to 50 K and then it decreases abruptly, showing the onset of antiferromagnetic interactions. Since the intramolecular (intracross) distances between the copper ions are very large (12.82–17.98 Å), we discarded these exchange pathways. The strongest copper–copper exchange interaction is supposed to occur between Cu1 and Cu2, belonging to neighboring tetranuclear units and connected through their basal and apical positions. The distance between these copper ions is 5.507 Å. Since the magnetic orbital for the square pyramidal geometry, dx2–y2, is located in the basal plane, the exchange interaction between Cu1 and Cu2 is expected to be quite weak. Indeed, the best fit to the data, using the classical Bleaney–Bowers equation multiplied by 2, leads to J = −1.50 cm–1, g = 2.02 (H = −JS 1 S 2 ). The χMT versus T curve for 2 is presented in Figure S12 of the . The χMT product is 0.38 cm3 mol–1 K at 291 K, as expected for a noninteracting copper(II) ion with g = 2.0. Upon cooling, χMT remains constant down to 45 K and then it decreases, showing the onset of antiferromagnetic interactions. The strongest copper–copper exchange interaction is expected to occur through the shortest distance between Cu1 and Cu2 (5.18 Å), belonging to the neighboring tetranuclear units forming a chain parallel to the crystallographic direction a, then the magnetic susceptibility data was fitted using the isotropic uniform Heisenberg chain model. We fitted the magnetic data using an empirical expression, which reproduces the Bonner and Fisher’s numerical calculations. The magnetic susceptibility data was described for this model with least-squares best fit parameters: g = 2.01 and |J| = 0.80 cm–1.

We fitted the magnetic data using an empirical expression, which reproduces the Bonner and Fisher's numerical calculations. The magnetic susceptibility data was described for this model with least-squares best fit parameters: g = 2.01 and |J| = 0.80 cm-1.

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  View of the tetranuclear copper metalloligand in complex 1 and its connectivities to the sodium ions. Symmetry codes: i = -1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z; ii = -x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; iii = -x, 1 - y, 1 - z; iv = -1 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z.

cln_elements.content: Formation of the layers in crystal 1 by connecting the tetranuclear complexes with Na1 ions. Symmetry codes: i = −x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; ii = 1 – x, 1 – y, −z; iii = 2 – x, 0.5 + y, −0.5 – z; iv = 2 + x, y, −1 + z; v = −x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; vi = 1 – x, −y, −z; vii = 1 + x, 0.5 – y, −0.5 + z.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Formation of the layers in crystal 1 by connecting the tetranuclear complexes with Na1 ions. Symmetry codes: i = -x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; ii = 1 - x, 1 - y, -z; iii = 2 - x, 0.5 + y, -0.5 - z; iv = 2 + x, y, -1 + z; v = -x, -0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; vi = 1 - x, -y, -z; vii = 1 + x, 0.5 - y, -0.5 + z.

cln_elements.content: The connectivity of the tetranuclear copper(II) crosses in 1. The sulfonyl oxygen atoms have been removed for clarity; the phenylene groups have been represented as thick lines, the crosses being drawn with different colors. (a) Top view, the sodium ions are not represented. (b) Lateral view. Symmetry codes: i = −1 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z; ii = x, 0.5 – y, 0.5 + z; iii = −1 + x, y, z; iv = −1 – x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; v = −1 + x, 1 + y, z.

The sulfonyl oxygen atoms have been removed for clarity; the phenylene groups have been represented as thick lines, the crosses being drawn with different colors. (a) Top view, the sodium ions are not represented. (b) Lateral view. Symmetry codes: i = -1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z; ii = x, 0.5 - y, 0.5 + z; iii = -1 + x, y, z; iv = -1 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; v = -1 + x, 1 + y, z.

cln_elements.content: Layers made by the connectivity between the tetranuclear units and sodium ions in 2. Symmetry codes: i = 2 – x, 0.5 – y, 2.5 – z; ii = 1 – x, 0.5 – y, 2.5 – z; iii = 1.75 – x, y, 2.75 – z; iv = 1 – x, 0.25 + y, 1.25 + z; v = 1 – x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 – z; vi = −0.25 + x, 0.25 + y, 2.5 – z; vii = 2 – x, −0.5 – y, 2.5 – z; viii = −0.25 + x, −y, −0.25 + z; ix = 2.25 – x, −0.25 – y, −0.5 + z; x = 2 – x, 0.75 + y, −0.25 + z; xi = 2.25 – x, y, 2.25 – z; xii = −0.5 + x, −0.25 – y, 2.25 – z; xiii = −0.5 + x, y, −0.5 + z.

cln_elements.content: Crystal packing of 2 evidencing the connectivity between tetranuclear copper(II) crosses. The phenylene groups have been represented as thick lines. (a) View along the b axis: the black diagonal line represents the Cu1···Na1 chain. (b) Detail of the packing diagram highlighting the interpenetrated brown and blue nets. For clarity, the central cross was replaced by an orange line and the sulfonyl oxygen atoms and the Na2 and Na3 ions have been removed. Solid thick lines represent the Cu1···Na1 chain; dashed lines represent the connection between crosses by a bridging Na5 ion, and the gray line represents the Cu2···Na2 chain. Symmetry codes: i = 2.25 – x, 0.75 – y, −0.5 + z; ii = 0.5 + x, 1 + y, −0.5 + z; iii = 0.5 + x, 0.75 – y, 2.25 – z; iv = 2.25 – x, 1 + y, 2.25 – z.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Crystal packing of 2 evidencing the connectivity between tetranuclear copper(II) crosses. The phenylene groups have been represented as thick lines. (a) View along the b axis: the black diagonal line represents the Cu1⋅⋅⋅Na1 chain. (b) Detail of the packing diagram highlighting the interpenetrated brown and blue nets. For clarity, the central cross was replaced by an orange line and the sulfonyl oxygen atoms and the Na2 and Na3 ions have been removed. Solid thick lines represent the Cu1⋅⋅⋅Na1 chain; dashed lines represent the connection between crosses by a bridging Na5 ion, and the gray line represents the Cu2⋅⋅⋅Na2 chain. Symmetry codes: i = 2.25 - x, 0.75 - y, -0.5 + z; ii = 0.5 + x, 1 + y, -0.5 + z; iii = 0.5 + x, 0.75 - y, 2.25 - z; iv = 2.25 - x, 1 + y, 2.25 - z.

metadata.title:
An Angular Bis-Oxamate Tecton for the Construction
of Heterobimetallic Coordination Polymers
